column1: People with diabetes can have nerve problems.
Tingling or burning in the feet and legs may be an early sign of nerve damage.
These feelings often start in your toes and feet, but can also start in the fingers and hands.
Nerve damage may cause you to lose feeling in your feet and legs.

Because of this, you may: - Not notice when you step on something sharp - Not know you have a blister or small wound on your toes - Not notice when you touch something too hot or too cold - Make it more likely to bump your toes or feet against objects - Can cause the joints in your feet to become damaged which can make it harder to walk - Can change the muscles in your feet which can cause increased pressure on your toes and balls of your feet - Can make it more likely for you to have infections of the skin on your feet People with diabetes may have problems digesting food.
They are: - Sudden fatigue - Sweating - Shortness of breath - Nausea - Vomiting Other symptoms of nerve damage are: - Sexual problems.
Women may have trouble with vaginal dryness or orgasm.
Your doctor can give you medicines to help with some of these symptoms.
- Medicines may help reduce painful symptoms in the feet, legs, and arms.
You may have to try different medicines to find one that reduces your pain.
- Your health care provider may give you medicines to help with problems digesting food or having a bowel movement.
